In 1974, Laithwaite was invited by the Royal Institution to give a talk on a subject of his own choosing. He decided to lecture about gyroscopes, a subject in which he had only recently become interested. His interest had been aroused by an amateur inventor named Alex Jones, who contacted Laithwaite about a reactionless propulsion drive he (Jones) had invented.

After seeing a demonstration of Jones's small prototype (a small wagon with a swinging pendulum which advanced intermittently along a table top), Laithwaite became convinced that "he had seen something impossible". In his lecture before the Royal Institution he claimed that gyroscopes weigh less when spinning and, to demonstrate this, he showed that he could lift a spinning gyroscope mounted on the end of a rod easily with one hand but could not do so when the gyroscope was not spinning. This was discussed in the BBC science series 'Horizon - 2015-2016: 2. Project Greenglow - The Quest for Gravity Control'.

In his 1974 lectures, Laithwaite suggested that Newton's laws of motion could not account for the behaviour of gyroscopes and Laithwaite suggested that they could be used as a means of reactionless propulsion. The members of the Royal Institution rejected his ideas and his lectures were not published at the time, a first for the Royal Institution. His lectures were subsequently published independently as Engineer Through The Looking-Glass and also on the Royal Institution website.

Despite this rejection and the fact that Laithwaite later acknowledged that gyroscopes behave fully in accord with Newtonian mechanics, he continued to explore gyroscopic behaviour, maintaining the belief that some form of reactionless propulsion could be derived from them. Laithwaite set up Gyron Ltd with William Dawson and, in 1993, applied for a patent entitled "Propulsion System". A United States Patent, Number 5860317, was granted in 1999. To this very day, research is conducted to account for the physics behind gyroscopic effects, directly pointing to Laithwaite's work as motivation.

Great stuff Derek! But actually, I think it literally does weigh less as you twirl the apparatus above your head. That first second or so as you start the rotation, there is a small downward force (which I think accounts for the little blip on the scale at 0:28) but as it spirals up it is losing angular momentum causing a small force in the opposite direction, making it feel slightly lighter. You'll note that if there were no affect the scale should actually register more weight as you push and accelerate something heavy upward over your head. The scale does not show this (unless that is the blip at 0:28, but I doubt it as I don't think you start to actually lift it until after) making me think it must effectively be a tiny bit lighter.

The scale with the little gyro shows no change because the gyro is on a balance with a weight and can teeter-totter but the gyro clearly does want to move up and down as you nudge the angular speed of the base (like at 3:39). If a spinning wheel is placed at the end of a long extended shaft where the free end is placed on a vertical stationary mast, and the spinning wheel at a radius R from the support mast, then as the wheel drops vertically, it tries to do this with the acceleration of 32 ft/sec^2 of gravity, which is relatively slow with respect to the velocity of the spinning mass particles. This was kind of a failure in explaining why the phenomenon happens.
So, the big factor that's not being addressed here isn't the flywheel's weight, or the shaft, or the rotation, or anything else --it's the person .

Derek weighs about 70kg, so a 20kg weight is only about 30% of his weight. But just as importantly, Derek is standing on the ground. Keep that fact in mind.

As he goes to lift the spinning flywheel (always in the direction that it wants to precess), the rotating mass of the flywheel starts to resist being turned at an angle to its axis; this is the "conservation of angular momentum", and it's why a gyroscope resists tilting. It really doesn't want to leave that axis! But Derek is forcing it to tilt, and it's not happy about that, so it starts pushing back, in the form of transferring some of that energy of the rotating mass, through the handle, into him , in the form of torque. Now, bearing in mind that Derek's weight is 3.5 times the weight of the flywheel and handle, he's already pretty well set-up to counteract that torque. And so long as he's gripping the handle firmly (which is easy to do), his arm doesn't have to do much work; all it has to do is to provide an unyielding connection between the handle and the ground, through his body.

As he turns while holding the handle, the angular momentum is transferred into the handle in the form of torque, and thereby into his hand. His hand doesn't let the shaft turn, so the momentum keeps getting transferred further and further -- through his arm, his torso, his legs, his feet, and finally to the ground. All of those together easily counteract the flywheel's "objection" to having its angular momentum changed. As long as he keeps turning, the flywheel will keep trying to precess, and trying to remain in the same plane, but he's not letting it do the latter, so that energy is transferred in the form of torque which, when meeting with the resistance of his hand and the mass of his body, and the unyielding ground, takes the flywheel in the only direction left to go: up, until it can return to being in the same plane it wanted to remain in, in the first place.

Just to add to the explanation: The gyroscope only feels lighter, because angular rotation is being converted to precession, and at certain times to vertical movement within the system. The system being the flywheel, the man, potential energy, kinetic energy and the ground. His arm does less work in raising the gyroscope, but he does more work in rotating himself, effectively increasing the rate of precession, and transferring energy to and from the flywheel. His total energy expenditure, plus the energies transferring to and from the flywheel rotation, are exactly the same as the energy used in simply lifting a stationary mass of 19 kg, but different muscles are being used to accomplish the task.

As he rotates himself faster, lifting the flywheel, the total rotational speed of the flywheel increases by an amount equal to his rotation about the vertical axis plus the rotational speed of the flywheel.

(Edit: To explain the next sentences, in a frictionless system, the flywheel would gain rotational speed in proportion to the man's rotational speed - every turn he makes is one extra turn to the flywheel, and as he slows down, the flywheel slows down by that much. In practice, the flywheel slows all of the time, because of friction but less so as he turns himself faster.)

Energy is thus transferred via his work in rotating himself plus the gyroscope. When he lowers the gyroscope, his rotational speed reduces, as does the speed of rotation of the flywheel. Energy is being transferred back from the flywheel. The residual precession, as he holds the gyroscope horizontally, represents the losses through friction, as the flywheel slows down. That's why a fixed gyroscope will gradually lower its shaft's free end to horizontal and below, until it strikes an object, and then transfers its remaining rotational energy to the obstruction, through noise, heat, and the disturbance of the momentum of the object. It sometimes runs away across a surface, or even shatters itself, whilst giving up that energy.

The two measured weight displacements on the scale are the peak points during which energies are being transferred. It can be seen from the graph that the increase in measured weight x the area under the curve and the 'neutral point is approximately equal and opposite to the area above the curve x the measured weight. (The discrepancy is mainly due to the man working to adapt to the changing forces between his arms and the gyroscope, and to friction.) Thus no net 'lifting force' results, and the laws momentum / thermodynamics are satisfied. In fact, if anything, the larger increase in measured weight than the measured decrease, proves that, if anything, energy is lost, and no net 'lift' has occurred.

Unfortunately, Professor Laithwaite had misunderstood what he was saying. Sadly, he lost his job, after losing credibility because of that error and he died with a somewhat unbalanced mind, in many peoples' estimation. In other respects, the Professor was a brilliant man, and people tend to forget that fact, because mistakes are much easier to sensationalise.

Ya know... I think this phenomenon has something to do with moment of inertia.

When the weight is not spinning, if you grab it right at it's center of mass and raise it up above your head, all of the gravitational energy is going directly down into your hand. Because of this, you would expect to see a spike in the weight on the scale (if you were standing on the scale), because as you push up on the weight, there is an equal and opposite reaction down onto the scale, and that downward force would also be significant and obvious to the arm pressing it up.

But when you're holding it at the end of the stick, further away from it's center of mass, the pull of gravity is not a direct downward force on your hand, it is now a torque on your hand. When the weight is spinning, the majority of that torque is now converted into gyroscopic procession. It isn't the spinning that causes it to process, but rather the torque that gravity creates in the direction that it wants to fall. That means the downward force of gravity is being counteracted partially by the force of your hand pushing up and partially by the motion of gyroscopic procession.

Instead of the downward force of gravity being overcome by your arm alone, the force is now distributed partially into your arm, and partially into the circular motion of the procession. This is why the more procession you have, the lighter it feels to your arm, and the slower the procession, the heavier it seems to get. You're simply allowing the procession to do more or less of the lifting, leaving the remainder to be lifted by your arm.

If you're having trouble understanding gyroscopic precession, allow me to explain it in simpler terms. 


In the video, they explain precession in terms of torque vectors. You don't really need to know anything about that. Think of the wheel as an equatorial orbit around the Earth. Pretend you're looking at the orbit straight on so it looks like a rocket on a line. If you wanted to go north, then you'd probably burn north and the line will translate upwards with your rocket. But this isn't the case because you're in an orbit and basically "spinning" in a circle. So instead of the line following the rocket up, the line and rocket keep their position, but the end of the line in which the rocket is orbiting to will rotate upwards. So you're basically changing the path to where the rocket will eventually end up 90 degrees in front of it's current position in the orbit.

So how does this apply to the wheel? Well if you think about it, gyroscopic precession is simply a redirection of an applied force to 90 degrees forward in the rotation of the wheel. So in this video, the spinning wheel is trying to be rotated by gravity so that the side facing away from the shaft will be towards the ground. But because the wheel is spinning, it redirects the force of gravity on the wheel 90 degrees out of phase so that it rotates it from left to right instead of up and down. We can also tell that the wheel is spinning clockwise due to the direction it precesses, as the force is is rotated 90 degrees in front in the direction of rotation.

Okay, but how does this apply to the wheel going up and down if you speed up or slow down the precession? Well, the same principal still applies, you apply a force to try to change its rotation from left to right, and so due to the principal, it will be redirected so it's rotating up and down instead!

Anyways, this was too long of an explanation, but I hope it helped!

Listen up people, and very carefully. Forget about gyroscopic forces. They have nothing to do with anything when it comes to physical work or energy. Gyroscopic forces are fictitious, pseudo forces. They do not exist in inertial frames, and do not do work, because they are always orthogonal to the motion.
So, what do we have here then? Just the “golden rule” of mechanics - whatever you lose in displacement you gain in force.
When we try to lift non-spinning flywheel, we try to do it along the shortest trajectory – just up, which is about two lengths of an arm, i.e. ~ 1.3 meter. But when the flywheel is spinning, and Derek or Laithwaite are lifting it, it moves along one loop of helix, longer trajectory, like a screw (thanks to those fictitious forces, though). If the length of the shaft is 1 meter, plus arm, total radius is ~ 1.6 meters. So the length of the helix trajectory is ~ sqroot[(2*1.6*3.14)^2 + 1.3^2] ~ 10 meters, which is ~ 7.8 times greater. That is, the flywheel will feel ~7.8 times lighter.
Plus, on top of that, humanly physiological aspects – our capabilities and feelings are not linear, so, compared to 20 Kg, 3 Kg will feel like "a feather".

At 2 minutes 22 seconds an incorrect physics statement is made. The statement is:

"You only need to create an upward force equal to the wheel's weight", but that is not true. The upward force is much LESS than the wheel's weight, for, even when the wheel is held in the hand (not by the shaft), it is still heavier than when it is in gyroscopic procession.  The procession, itself, causes the wheel to have less "weight" relative to the hand that is holding it up.

The reason why a person is able to "lift" it (create additional force beyond the weight which is already factored into the total weight of the man and wheel according to the scale), is because it does not require a reverse (downward) force, which is why additional weight is not seen on the scale when he pulls it up. Normally, the scale would temporarily increase in weight as he pushed the weight up.

The reason for this effect is that the upward lift is derived from the spinning of the wheel. The wheel, infact, decreases in rotational speed on the shaft as it is elevated. Think of it as being similar to spinning a wheel up really fast, and then letting it go, traveling up a hill. As the wheel travels up the hill...the wheel will slow down, not just horizontally, but also rotationally, until it stops. If it is not braked at the top, it will descend downwards and regain its rotational speed once again as it accelerates back to the bottom of the hill. This whole process is identical to the gyroscopic effect, except it has no linear horizontal movement, and only a circular procession.

So, since all the lift is derived from the wheel itself slowing down as he lifts....the scale will not see a change in the weight from him lifting it up. And when he lowers it back down again, the rotational speed of the wheel on the shaft will once again increase.

Please note, when I speak of "rotational speed", I am not referring to the perimeter that the weight is traveling around his body in a circular fashion. I am referring, instead, to the actual spinning it is doing on the shaft.

The torque is not what makes it easily lifted above the head. The torque does contribute its portion, but it does not explain the rest of the portion. For, even without the torque, he still had an easier time raising the weight above his head than when it is not spinning, and being lifted above the head by the gripping of the wheel itself (and not the shaft). In essence, the torque is eliminated, but the weight is still heavy, and yet lifts more easily than without the spinning, while holding it at the wheel where no torque is needed. So yes...it, the upward force required to lift the weight, is still smaller than the amount needed if it were not spinning.

It's rare I disagree with Derek's methodology, but there is a rather serious technicality here.  I agree that the stationary weight of the gyroscope should be the same whether it spinning or not, but in the process of lifting it above his head, Derek is first accelerating it, then letting it decelerate.  He gives it an initial jerk with both hands so that it begins with some upward velocity (causing a clear jump on the scale that is somehow not recorded on his graph).
If he were then to apply an upward a force upon it equal to the force exerted by gravity, then its upward velocity would continue unhindered.  However, in order to allow it to decelerate, he must be applying a force less than that exerted by gravity.  According to Newton's second law this should also decrease the weight registered on the scale.
By my rough calculations, in two seconds it moves vertically by one metre, decelerating to zero vertical velocity at the top.  Using x = ut + 1/2 a t^2, this means the downward acceleration of the gyroscope is about 0.5 m/s/s for those two seconds, so the registered weight should decrease by the equivalent of 1kg.
When I closely look at the behaviour of the shaky scale in the video, it does indeed seem to spend those two seconds oscillating around 90 kg rather than 91kg.  However, Derek's own, rather subjective graphing of the scale readings conveniently comes out around exactly 91kg.  I think there might be a tiny bit of confirmation bias creeping in here!
Derek notes the large deviations when he lets the wheel fall after the lift and then catches it.  But, these same deviations should also be occurring to a lesser magnitude when he gently lifts the apparatus from waist-height to head-height.

Let's calculate the extra force we would expect to see on the scale. Judging from the video you raised the flywheel in 2 seconds and raised it about 1 meter. Assuming you delivered constant force we can calculate:

d=0.5*a*t^2
1=0.5*a*4
a=0.5 m/s^2

F=m*a
F=10 N

10 N more on the scale equals 1 kg more weight; you need a better scale to measure that (and your body should be more rigid). Newton could still be wrong, but you can't conclude that from this video.

---

Of course when you drop it, it is noticable. Let's say you let it free fall for 0.66 meter and then catch it in 0.33 meter. In the free fall, he scale would give your body weight. The energy the flywheel accumulates in a 0.66 meter drop is:

E=m*g*h
E=132 J

You then catch it:

E=F*d
132=F*0.33
F=400 N

So during the catch you would weigh around 40 kg more than bodyweight, which seems about correct with the experiment results.

"Torque" is not what makes an object feel heavy. A 40-lb dumbbell should not have a torque, yet it will feel just as heavy as a none-rotating flywheel when a person tries to lift it over the shoulder.

The flywheel does obey Newton's first law. An object will remain in motion, which in this case is rotational and not translational. A heavy wheel that maintains motion will resist any attempts at changing the axis of rotation. This is something that most motorcycle riders are familiar with.

The non-rotating mass feels heavier because the shoulder joint mechanics do not allow you distribute the work of lifting over a longer period of time.

EXPLAINING THE "LESS WEIGHT"
With a spinning gyro, to push it in one direction, makes it move at right-angles to your force. But you are still exerting a force. When the wheel rises above his head there is a (say) ten percent less force to lift it vertically (say 10 lb less). But there is a force at right-angles to the vertical that is 10 lb greater (against) your force input (you have to actually force it (side-ways) to keep your pivot stationary. Your body transforms this extra 10 lb force to the scales (like a bell-crank, from arm to body) to cancel the less down-ward force of the wheel's weight. So, even if the wheel has less vertical "weight", the scale still reads the same. With the wheel spinning, some of it's weight will be converted to a horizontal force that is equal to the "less weight" difference. 
One comment came to mind, and he said that this sort of physics is really involved and there are lot of things going on about this (it's complex). That said, we are now talking about internal forces and external forces.
CLOSED SYSTEM. Basically, an internal force is a body trying to put a force on it'self. It cant. It can only make something move that is part of the body. So a spaceship with no engine power cant make it'self move by using a robot arm (that comes from the same spaceship) putting a force on the same space ship. Nothing will happen, even when a force is applied to the robot arm. That is a closed system, or internal force. But the robot arm can turn a crank or whatever but it won't propel the space ship.
OPEN SYSTEM. This is one body (or bodies) putting a force on another body. This is external force, where the force comes from somewhere else, other than from itself. A rocket engine pushes other bodies away from it, causing a forward force. It's an external force cos the (other bodies) are moving from the rocket, away from the rocket. As long as the (other bodies) leave the rocket, it's an external force. And the (other bodies) can't be re-collected in any way by the rocket, otherwise it would become an internal force (a closed system) and there would be no thrust. This is why perpetual motion doesn't work. They are all internal force (closed systems).
And (unfortunately) the spinning wheel is a closed system and any forces are internal forces. Like the internal force of less weight but more side-ways force, reads the same on the scale. For the scale to change, you need an external force.
We tend to marvel at the slightly less weight of the wheel, but tend to ignore the same increase in side-ways force on the wheel.

Energy is, of course, conserved. When the flywheel spinning you are inputting energy with your torso and both arms to raise the apparatus. Initially you speed up the precession with your torso and auxilliary hand, which is then converted to lifting energy by virtue of the gyroscopic effect. After that your primary hand provides the remaining lifting energy necessary to lift the apparatus. This remaining energy may be delivered evenly over a considerable period of time, reducing peak power required.

More importantly controlling the wheel in motion is significantly easier because you can simply adjust its orientation by pushing harder/less hard in one direction: counter clockwise(from the view of your right wrist). Your upper arm muscle can remain relatively relaxed except when you consciously exert force to slow/speed up the procession.

On the other hand balancing the weight to make it steady requires constantly changing net torue direction. You need to turn the wheel clockwise when it gains anti-clockwise angular momentum from your shaky hand, and vice versa.
As a result both the extensor and flexor(opposing pair of muscles) of the upper arm are in a very tensed state so it can counteract unwanted spinning quickly and violently. Note that the muscles are fighting against each other, they tires quickly.

In the end the physical work done is the same(raised to the same height) but with stopped wheels the muscles tense, causing way more lactic acid accumulation and therefore 'tiredness'. The effort put into controlling the weight also gives a hard time to the bicep, because rotating the wrist can make the arm deviate from the optimum angle for lifting.

My question though has to do with relativity.  As I mentioned before, the scale is indirectly measuring the amount of mass of you and the spinning wheel.  If we look at the famous equation E=mc^2 though, we see that as energy increases, mass must increase as well.  Thus, as you increase the energy in the shaft by spinning it, does the mass of the shaft increase as well?  If this is the case, then the correct answer should actually be that the system weighs more while the shaft is spinning than while it is not spinning, since the shaft has ever so slightly more mass while spinning than it does at stand still!  Of course, this extra mass would be far too small to observe, but it might be there nonetheless.  Keep in mind, I'm only a high school physics student, but I thought this was interesting and wanted to know what other people thought.  Thanks Derek, keep making the awesome videos that inspire me every day!
